review.title: Friendships, Rivalries, and Trysts: Characterizing Relations between Ideas in Texts
review.abstract: Understanding how ideas relate to each other is a fundamental question in many domains, ranging from intellectual history to public communication. Because ideas are naturally embedded in texts, we propose the first framework to systematically characterize the relations between ideas based on their occurrence in a corpus of documents, independent of how these ideas are represented. Combining two statistics --- cooccurrence within documents and prevalence correlation over time --- our approach reveals a number of different ways in which ideas can cooperate and compete. For instance, two ideas can closely track each other's prevalence over time, and yet rarely cooccur, almost like a "cold war" scenario. We observe that pairwise cooccurrence and prevalence correlation exhibit different distributions. We further demonstrate that our approach is able to uncover intriguing relations between ideas through in-depth case studies on news articles and research papers.

sections.text: As discussed in the introduction, we focus on two dimensions to quantify the relationships between ideas: 1. sections.text: To give an overview of the four relationship types in Fig. 1, we first examine the empirical distributions of the two interesting statistics across idea pairs. sections.heading: 3.2 Relative Strength of Extreme Pairs
sections.text: We are interested in how our framework can identify fascinating relationships between ideas. These potentially interesting pairs are likely to correspond to the extreme points in each quadrant rather than those around the origin, where PMI and prevalence correlation are both close to zero. Here, we will compare the relative strength of extreme pairs in each dataset. We will discuss how these extreme pairs validate existing knowledge and new hypotheses through case studies in § 4. sections.heading: 4.2 Ethnicity Keywords in Immigration
sections.text: Our observation begins with a first-class relationship between Latin American and Asian immigrants. Although these words probably co-exist, their prevalence patterns differ, with the discussion of Asian immigrants in the 1990s giving way to a focus on the word Latin American immigrants since 2000. Possible theories to explain this observation include that undocumented immigrants are generally perceived as a Latino problem or that Latin American voters increasingly influence U.S. elections. In addition, Latin America maintains head-to-head relations with two subgroups of Latin American immigrants: Haiti and Cuba. Specifically, the strength of the relationship with Haiti ranks 18th in head-to-head relations. Meanwhile, Haitian and Cuban voters have a friendship relationship that is in turn consistent with the structural equilibrium theory. The decreasing prevalence of Haitian and Cuban relations may explain the shift in the geographical focus of recent immigration to the U.S. and the fact that the majority of the Latino population has some relevance to the American population.

sections.heading: 4.3 Relations between Topics in ACL
sections.text: Finally, we analyze the relationships between themes in the ACL anthology. It turns out that "machine translation" is central to the relationships in all four types (fig. 8).7 It is part of the strongest relationship in all four types except tryst (place 5).The complete relationship curve shows further patterns. Friendship shows transitivity: both "machine translation" and "word alignment" have similar relationships to other themes. But such transitivity does not apply to all areas: although the prevalence of "rule, forest methods" correlates with both "machine translation" and "emotion analysis," "mood analysis" rarely takes place with "rule," because in the ranking we filtered a topic where the top words are ions, ions, system, process, language, one, one, input, natural language, processing, grammar. For the purposes of this corpus, this is effectively a stop topic.

sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: Most studies have so far examined the trends of ideas individually (Michel et al., 2011; Hall et al., 2008; Rule et al., 2015). Hall et al. (2008), for example, present various trends in our own computer-aided linguistic community, including the rise of statistical machine translation. More recently, rhetorical framing has been used to predict such patterns (Prabhakaran et al., 2016). An exception is that Shi et al. (2010) use prevalence correlations to analyze delay relationships between issues in publications and research grants. Anecdotally, Grudin (2009) observes a "head-head relationship" between artificial intelligence and human-computer interaction in research funding. To our knowledge, however, our work is the first to systematically characterize the relationships between ideas.

sections.heading: 6 Concluding Discussion
sections.text: We have proposed a method to characterize relationships between ideas in texts through the lens of chance within documents and the prevalence correlation over time. For the first time, we observe that the distribution of paired coincidences is unimodal, while the distribution of paired prevalence correlations is not always unimodal, and show that they are positively correlated. This combination suggests four types of relationships between ideas, and these four types are all found to varying degrees in our experiments. We illustrate our calculation method through exploratory studies of news organizations and scientific research papers. We not only confirm existing knowledge, but also suggest hypotheses about the use of Arabs and Islams in terrorism and Latinos and Asians in immigration. It is important to note that the relationships found with our approach depend on the way ideas are presented and the source of texts.
